and low carbon options are more acceptable when people strongly value protecting other people and

Energy System Transitions in the Context
The attractiveness of energy sector mitigation ultimately depends on the way that it provides benefits
the many different priorities that societies value
. While costs and benefits of climate mitigation are often considered in the context of pure
for example, GDP effects or changes in
should be viewed with a broader lens that accounts for the many ways that the energy system interacts
growth and development strategies, but rather as a key element of those strategies.
Cost reductions in key technologies, particularly in electricity and light
transitions in some sectors and regions
may be on par with or superior to those of an emissions
carbon transitions, these transitions may still be
rable when accounting for health impacts and other co
Past assessments have quantified the aggregat
e economic costs for climate change mitigation using
different metrics, for example carbon prices, GDP losses, investments in energy infrastructure, and
energy system costs. Assessments of mitigation costs from integrated assessment and energy system
s vary widely. For example, scenarios include carbon prices in 2030 of less than USD 20/t
depending on the region, sector boundary, and methodology (e.g.
(Bauer et al. 2016; Oshiro et al. 2017; Vaillancourt et al. 2017; Chen et al. 2019; Brouwer et al. 2016)
Those arise both from different me
uncertainties in key factors that drive costs
Recent developments, however, raise the prospect that economic outcomes could be substantially
superior to prior estimates, particularly i
f key technologies continue to improve rapidly. In some regions
and circumstances, particularly in the electricity sector, near
term mitigation may well lead to superior
economic outcomes than continuing to invest in and utilize emissions
. Given the importance of electricity decarbonization in near
term mitigation strategies (see Section 6.7.1), decreasing costs of solar PV, wind power, and batteries
